title: Hackers use malicious imageless QR codes to evade defenses
executive_summary: A recent phishing campaign is abusing QR codes rendered purely with HTML table elements instead of embedded images, allowing the codes to slip past many email defenses.
These QR codes still scan like traditional codes but can redirect victims to malicious sites that harvest credentials or deliver malware.
what_happened: Rather than including a QR image in the email body, attackers build the QR pattern using hundreds of tiny HTML table cells with black and white background colors, forming a scannable code.
Because many secure email gateways focus on traditional image scanning, this HTML-based QR code technique can evade detection and be delivered to users’ inboxes.
Campaign emails observed between late December 2025 contained minimal lure text and a block that appears as a QR code, urging the recipient to scan it with a mobile device.
who_is_affected: Email users globally who receive unsolicited messages containing QR codes.
Organizations relying solely on traditional email defense tools without DOM-aware inspection.
Individuals who scan QR codes without verifying their source or intent.
attack_flow: Threat actor crafts an HTML email with a table-based QR code rather than an image.
Email gateways fail to flag the code as malicious due to lack of image scanning triggers.
User scans the rendered QR with a mobile device, unknowingly navigating to a malicious URL.
The destination site may harvest credentials, deliver malware, or perform other malicious actions.
business_impact: Credential theft or fraud following phishing success.
Malware or ransomware deployment via URLs reached through malicious QR codes.
Increased support burden from compromised endpoints caused by phishing.
risk_reason: By moving beyond image-based QR codes and using HTML rendering, attackers can evade many existing security filters, making this form of phishing more effective and harder to detect.
what_usually_goes_wrong: Security tools that rely primarily on image scanning miss non-image QR patterns.
Users see a familiar QR code and scan without suspicion.
Defenders underestimate the threat posed by non-standard code renderings.

immediate: Warn users that scanning QR codes from unsolicited emails carries risk equivalent to clicking unknown links.
Update email security gateways to use DOM-aware analysis that recognizes table-constructed QR codes.
short_term: Monitor for spikes in phishing attempts using QR codes and suspicious domain redirects.
Implement warnings or policies around QR code scanning for enterprise devices.
long_term: Educate staff on quishing (QR-based phishing) threats as part of security awareness training.
Collaborate with email filter vendors to improve detection of non-image QR encodings.

what_this_does_not_mean: All QR codes in email are malicious — many are legitimate.
QR scanning apps or devices are compromised as a whole.

signs: Unusual outbound traffic following email QR scans.
Users reporting unexpected redirects after scanning codes in email.
alerts: Multiple users scanning similar QR codes and visiting the same suspicious domain.
Email systems flagging dense table structures consistent with HTML-based QR constructs.
